author: Michael
title: iPhone User Review
content:
If you’re using an iPhone (like me) be aware that the app to customize how these work is only available for Android. That means Apple users are stuck with the out-of-the-box configuration. This may pose a problem for some.

The good:
The controls are fairly straight forward. I’ve listened to music and made phone calls. All were great sounding and clear. I’ve had people tell me how great the mic sounds.
They are comfortable. They ship with different sizes of inserts for a good fit.
They are sweat “proof.” I’ve heard this claim before and had other earbuds ruined by sweat. So we’ll see how these hold up in the long run. Airpods are not even sweat resistant. So they wouldn’t be my first choice for workouts.
They can work independently. You don’t need both buds in. They have the same configs right out of the box. So you can use just one if you need and not have to have a different set of controls.

The not-so-good:
You’re stuck with the configuration. The tap controls are easy. Play/pause, skip/reverse, answer/decline, etc. are all just tap sequences. Press and hold activates Siri.
There is no volume control on the buds. That is, unless you have an Android and can change the config. But, since this is a review for iPhone users, there is no volume control on the buds.
The quick-start directions are great for Android users. The case needs to be open and the buds inside it for it to pair. Some may already know this from other types of buds, but these are my first... and I had to Google it.

Are they good? Yes. Would I like them to be more Apple friendly? Yes. I’m going to keep them and just suffer through the volume control thing. The sweat-proofing and sound are more important to me.
You make the call for you. I didn’t see many iPhone reviews or information. So I wanted to share with others who may be looking.

author: BigAl
title: Meh
content: I've got a iPhone SE, but hate the look and sound quality of the Apple wired earbuds, and since the wireless ones have the same concept, i opted for these instead. I use earbuds for the gym, listen to music and watch video's while working out, so i wanted something that had noise cancelling.. these do that, sorta.. it comes with 3 different size gel tips..i had to put in the large ones, and even then, i have a difficult time getting a seal..so i moisten them before inserting which kinda helps..inserting and removing these are kinda difficult too, since they're 'rounded'..making it hard to grasp with the fingers..once in the ear though, you don't feel them at all! It's quite remarkable..and they stay put very well too. I have had connection issues though even though they are Bluetooth 5.0 and my phone is always in my pocket or no more than 2 feet from me at all times.. i have to go to Bluetooth settings and 'disconnect' them after each use or to reset them while in use, which is a pain in the butt.. the case is smooth and rounded, making it difficult to grasp when in a gym bag.. the battery life is superb though..kudos Samsung for that.. however, there is only one LED to indicate if the earbuds are 'set' in the cases cradle..i'd prefer two LED's, one for each ear bud... how do i know they're both being charged with only one LED? My biggest complain, and something no reviewer addressed (and i watched a ton of video reviews before purchase), is that there is no iOS app for these.. I can't see battery status, change EQ settings, or anything that the Android app can do. Why release a product for one format but not the other? I was assured they are working on one, but couldn't guarantee when it will be available.. I registered them on the Samsung site, indicating my OS in hopes of an alert when the app is available..i was told to keep checking back on the website..Really? For a tech company, that seems pretty prehistoric to me.. without the app, you're get pretty decent sound, although my $19 Anker soundbuds sound better..been a musician my whole life so sound quality is pretty important.. music and quality sound can inspire .. these kinda just are "Meh"...

author: Jesus R.
title: So far So Good!
content: Just had them a couple hours and pairing them was easy. I love these, i have small ears and they fit great. The bass is good for me; i don't get why people criticized it.If you want to increase volume keep in mind that the buds have their own volume control. Fast shipping made these worth every penny. Will update review if anything changes.

author: Lexy Zorotrian
title: Tapping sucks overall great
content: I love these little things! I’m 100% and apple user. But I just can’t stand the apple pods since they’re so uncomfortable. So I got these and I definitely don’t regret it. The case is small and cute.  Comes with different size rubber pieces. People hear me when I talk with them. Only thing I really struggle with is the whole tapping thing. Tap once to pause, tap twice to skip. It only works half the time. I’ll tap twice to skip my song and it only registers one tap so my music will stop. Really bugs me, but I have an Apple Watch so I can just skip my songs that way no big deal

author: Angel Cotto
title: Great buds, for the most part.
content: They're great for the most part, but whenever I put them in my pocket for a walk it starts skipping uncontrollably, also after a while of skipping tracks with the touch pads they go crazy skipping to the point that I have to disconnect them and reconnect for them to work properly again. I have a Galaxy S9+

author: Ryan C.
title: Fantastic Wireless Earbuds
content:
Pros:
-seamless connectivity with my Note 9 running One UI
-Wireless charging
-Small form factor
-No "master bud" trait (where one bud is dominant, and if it dies the other one can't be used)

Not really a con, the sound quality is better than the airpods (first gen at this time), but not quite as rich as the Bose Sound Sports.  But the Bose make me feel like I'm wearing satellite dishes, and I haven't finished playing with my eq setting for the Samsung's yet.

Edit: After about a week of tweaking eq settings and trying different ear-tips and wings, these buds sound just as good as the Bose' if not better.

author: Ejtsecond
title: Premium Sound
content: I tested the new Samsung Galaxy Buds for an extensive period. I wanted to test the functionality of the headphones at home, work, and in between. I was really surprised at the sound quality. I did not expect such a broad range of sound from such a little device. The paring process was really simple while using the Galaxy S10. My phone recognized the buds as soon as I opened the charging case. Then I opened the Galaxy Wearable app and I was notified of an update for the buds immediately. I must say that the Galaxy buds are comfortable and stay in ear while walking, jogging or running. I didn’t experience the normal ear soreness from extended usage as with some other headphones. While listening to music, the Galaxy buds did a good job of removing background noise. I couldn’t hear much of my surroundings at all. Then, I tested the Ambient Aware feature while at work, and this was really useful. Most people did not recognize that I even had headphones in. The Ambient Aware feature allowed me to hear my surroundings by using the built in mic on the headphones. Portability is also a big plus. Being able to pop the Galaxy buds in and out and having a charging case is a useful tool to have. The charging case is vital at work too. I can get about 5 hours of music listening before having to charge the buds. The coolest feature is having the ability to charge the case and the Galaxy buds. I can get through a whole 9 hour office day having to charge the buds for a few minutes a day. Overall, I recommend the Galaxy Buds for anyone who wants a premium sound from affordable headphones.

author: Nizo
title: Sweeeeet
content:
I have to admit, I was a little worried based on some of the negative reviews, but so far they have been great. Samsung has updated the software twice in the last week. Gets plenty loud without blaring and I love the fact I can use one bud if I want instead of both. I have been wearing one under my headset at work  and it has been comfortable throughout the day. Nobody knows I have it in! 😁

Battery life has been great for me running them at about 70% max volume. All in all I am quite pleased. Should also mention I've gotten no complaints on my sound quality during the calls I've taken on them.

author: Ryan
title: These are great when paired with a Galaxy phone.
content:
As a Galaxy phone owner I pulled the trigger on these despite reading some complaints and I am happy to report these are great ear buds. They are very comfortable, the sound is good once you use the right settings, and the battery life is great.

One thing I want to say is that I honestly believe many of the complaints about poor volume and Bass are due to operator error by not using the right settings on your phone. Low volume is easily fixed by enabling "media volume sync" on your phone. As for the bass, I use the Samsung music app. Once I enabled the Dolby Atmos feature it gave my music much richer sound and deeper bass. So the pro tip is use the equalizer on your phone not the buds. Also using the right sized rubber bud fittings is key to good sound. If these aren't in your ear enough just push them in a bit, the difference in sound quality is huge.

One complaint I do have is the ambient noise feature. It amplifies everything a little too much. A light breeze that would normally not be noticeable will sound like constant wind whistling in your ears with the ambient noise feature on. Its very annoying so I leave it disabled.

Other than that these are great buds. I strongly recommend them for Samsung Galaxy phone owners. I have had ZERO connectivity or dropped connection issues that others reported with non Galaxy phones.

author: Amazon Customer
title: They are ok but sometimes crackle/lose connection with can kill the mood
content: This earbuds are nice, but they lose connection/crackle offen when I am outside and sometimes inside not sure what causing it but with if it has Bluetooth 5 like it says then this shouldn't happen..I have a Samsung Galaxy S9+ so I don't think it my phone... I may just return this and get my Anker airbuds again a least I know those work prefect

author: Nate S
title: Now an Ex-Samsung Fanboy
content:
This review is based on my experience using these buds at work with my brand new Samsung Galaxy S10 Plus (and the Wearables App).

I've had every Galaxy S phone since the S7, but this is the first pair of Samsung wireless buds I've ever owned. Previously, I'd just buy a $20 pair of bluetooth headphones on Amazon, which would last about a year before needing to be replaced. Those $20 headphones never had half the issues I've had in the past week with these!

My main issue with these buds is that everyday they disconnect and reconnect about 20x. Sometimes they'll say that they're connected and then I go to play music and they'll disconnect and reconnect, but still not play anything. I usually have to turn bluetooth off and on to get them to reconnect properly, and even that sometimes doesn't work, so I'll pull out the charging case, put them in, close the case, and re-open it. Eventually, they'll connect properly, but playing music shouldn't be a 10 step procedure. I have the stupid wearables app, and everything, the buds have a full charge, and they just don't want to connect properly. It's maddening, ding, ding, in your ear every time it decides to drop and reconnect because you tried to play a song.

My next issue is the call quality, I use these at work, where I take at least 10 calls a day. About 4 times now, I've heard myself echoing back at me, which is incredibly distracting when you're trying to have a conversation. It'll just start out of nowhere too, mid call. Other times, the mic is just really bad, people complain that they can't hear me and I have to speak up. It does nothing to cancel out background noise. I've been told to put myself on mute several times during conference calls with these buds (in the same office where my $20 buds had no issues).

Lastly, the wireless charging seems to be pretty spotty. It'll be charging and then all of a sudden lose connection, and need to be re-positioned on the charger.

At this point, I don't know if the issues I described are due to a defect, or issues with the Galaxy S 10 Plus, or what, but it's just unacceptable. A $1000 phone and a $120 pair of buds that can't seem to work right together just goes to show that Samsung doesn't know what they're doing. I'm sending back the buds, and looking into replacing the S10+ with a Google Pixel 3a XL.

author: Tim
title: AirPod Killers
content:
Saying that these are the equivalent for Android as the AirPods are for Apple would be taking away form the Galaxy Buds. I've owned both, and would pick these anyday of the week over AirPods. The sound quality is superior, and the aesthetics (personal opinion) are much better. They stay in without issue and can be worn for hours without any discomfort. I would recommend trying the different sized tips included. When testing them, leave them in for at least 10/15 minutes to get a good idea, also shake your head around and make sure they are secure.

Overall, the only complaint I would have is the the battery, but with wireless charging and the ability of the Galaxy S10+ to PowerShare, that's no problem.

author: Trinchii
title: They aren't bad headphones, but for the price it's not really worth it.
content: I just expected more, for the price at least. The headphones cut out while waking constantly, you can walk a good 100ft away from your phone and still use it so long as your skull isn't in the way, the noise cancelation works but the ambient voice option only works for about five feet so it's useless, the sound is fine, sometimes it says it's playing music but there's no sound, sometimes I have to pair both headphones, sometimes it refuses to play more than a few minutes unless my s10 remains unlocked, the sound it makes when it dies is exactly the same as the sound it makes when it shuts off for an update so that's confusing, they are slender so that's cool, my ears don't like these at much as my old 35$ pair, there's no flashing light so they are sneaky, they're shiny so not too sneaky, the touch pad is both too sensitive and also not sensitive enough (ie it's too easy to double click but also a single stand of hair can block your finger), the battery life isn't bad but it's not great either, wireless charging from my phone is pretty rad in a pinch, Bixby doesn't make a distinct enough sound when activated, honestly I had less complaints about my 35$ wireless headphones.

author: Ray
title: Great pair of premium wireless headphones
content: Been using the Samsung Galaxy Buds since early march when the S10+ was released. Have had some time to get familiar with all the features and functions. I use them every day at work, GYM and at home. The adaptive dual microphone feature is great at work, if I have someone talk to me while I’m listing to music, or if my desk phone rings I can still hear it. The battery has lasted me roughly 5 hours of straight usage, mixed talk, and music. The charging case will re-charge them, but since I remove them here and there and dock them the battery can last closer to the advertised 10-11hours. Plus owning a Samsung S10+ with reverse charging I can give them a boost of power while on the go if necessary. These have to be some of the best sounding headphones I have ever owned, I used to think my AKG over the hear headset was the best, but they are bulky and not work, or GYM friendly. The should quality when wearing both is immersive, and can make you forget you're in a loud office or loud GYM. Bass and Treble are balanced and offer great voice and music capability.  Often use them after work at the GYM, and having them be sweat resistant is great! Plus, they don’t fall out or feel obtrusive in my hear during running or cardio. My old AKG wires headphones would prevent me from enjoying my work out with cords to adjust. Using them is simple enough, just make sure to select the right size earpiece, I found the default one it ships with fits perfectly. But there are optional S, L in the box. Controlling the Buds is done with your finger via touch, you can take calls, end them, change tracks, turn up or down the volume. And if you remove them it will pause the music which is great so you don’t ever miss a beat. To pair them to my S10, all you have to do is open the case, and the Phone UI will detect them and display the Galaxy Buds on screen with name, and battery level. So, pairing them takes but a few seconds. I was able to also use them on my iPhone Xr, different setup process, but simple none the less. Fist make sure they are not currently synced to Android by turning off Bluetooth on Android device, the open the clamshell case and have iOS search for Bluetooth devices, it will show up as Galaxy Buds (####). Select the corresponding Buds and pair. Once paired they will work like any other Bluetooth headset for iOS. The only downside to iOS is that firmware updates will not work, you will need to re-sync them to Android via the Gear App for them to check and keep to up to date. Overall these earbuds are some of the best I have ever owned, and you will not be disappointed, they come in Black, White and Yellow to match any personality and mood.

author: CDM
title: Terrible range...
content:
Simply fantastic. Fit is perfect and sound quality is awesome. Great Job Samsung...
8/15/19: Update... I wish I could return. Soumd is great but the range is terrible. If you have your phone by your side while walking they cut in and out. And if you try to put your phone in your pocket, forget it. I have called Samsung and performed all of the updates and they still do the same thing. I will plan to look else where for my next pair.

author: Christopher Watts
title: nice battery life, great sound
content: I bought these because of the battery life and I figured the higher price would mean great sound. I waited a while before reviewing this product just to see if they would last and they have. Very satisfied. I bought them to cancel out the absolutely terrible music my work plays over the speakers. These buds can be very loud too. I don't have the volume turned up at all, but you could play music very loudly if you wanted (not recommended from me though). They fit nicely into my ears and don't fall out at all. They are comfortable and don't have any weird protrusions that make them uncomfortable to wear. The buttons are easy to click. I would recommend getting a small plastic sandwich bag to put the case in for carrying it around in your pocket to prevent dust from getting into the charge port though. It's a simple and non-intrusive way to keep it clean. I had to dig dust and lint out of my phone charge port eventually because of this problem, so it does happen eventually.

author: M P
title: Has connectivity issues
content:
I just got my Galaxy Buds yesterday, so I will update the review if the issue is resolved.

I'll start off with the positives. The battery life is great, lasting the whole work day and well into the night on a single charge (with occasionally putting them in the case to charge during meetings). They're relatively comfortable to wear for long periods of time. The case is decent quality and offers the option of wireless charging and USB-C charging.

Now on to the bad I've experienced. When walking with my phone in my pocket (S8), listening to Spotify, the music constantly cuts out, occasionally echos, and gets distorted. I thought it might have been a bad data connection so I tried playing some music that I had stored on my phone, but experienced the same results. I was hoping to use this when working out, going for a run, etc., but if I can't even walk down the street without connectivity issues, I can only imagine what vigorous work would do to it.

The case construction itself leaves much to be desired. It's made out of a cheap plastic and I could see the lid easily breaking off if my three year old gets ahold of it.

Bottom line: The Galaxy Buds are not for everyone. I would recommend them to those who are relatively staionary and don't have little kids. If you live any kind of active lifestyle, you should stay away until they update the issues they're currently having.

author: Awesome McNeato
title: Good sound, Awful smell
content: To connect with my note 8, bt range could be better, sound it good. There was a big shipping mixup and they were 6 days late on a prime shipment, annoying, but got here eventually. My only big beef is the super weird smell of the buds. Very strong chemical smell, almost like an industrial sanitizer? The smell stays on your fingers and ears :( its overwhelming.

author: Jonny Huff
title: Very poor phone call quality.
content:
I hate to leave negative reviews. I'll only leave a negative review if I feel that people should know about a serious issue with a product. Especially a product over $100.

These Galaxy Buds are cool except for a few things that I could just not accept. Having owned multiple Bluetooth headsets of different makes and models I have to say that this has been my least favorite. I've owned 2 different LG headsets, a Bose headset and these.

- These were uncomfortable in my ears, even after changing to the smaller size of the rubber fittings.

- The sound quality of music and podcasts by no means impressed me (not that it was bad, just wasn't great). The sound at max volume is quite low out of the box. This can be fixed though (after using Google to find the solution) by downloading the Galaxy Wearable app to increase the volume, which is a one and done resolution.

- MOST IMPORTANTLY, the phone call quality is horrible. I called several people while wearing these to find out that people could barely hear me at all. This could be because the microphones (which are on both buds) are all the way back by your ear. But it's 2019 so I wouldn't think this should be an issue. After searching on Google to find a solution I just came across pages and pages of Samsung's community forums of people searching for the same answers I was with no solutions.

I know Samsung is a good brand, I expected better.

author: Aaron
title: Better than the Jabras
content:
tl;dr These are a better fit than the Jabra Elite Actives and have better audio quality than Airpods when used with the larger silicone earbud tip. If you use these for the office and gym like me they are a good value. If you have an iPhone it likely won't work as well without the app so I wouldn't recommend these for Apple devices (I have a samsung personal phone and an apple work phone).

I've most recently tried out the Jabra Elite Active 65t headphones. They we pretty good and actually great when it came to call quality. However, they could never quite fit comfortably in my ear and so I couldn't use them for more than 10 minutes at a time without taking them out because my ear started hurting. I heard bad things about call quality and audio quality with the Galaxy Buds. I haven't used them for calling yet but compared to other headphones, they don't have the array of microphones so I can see why these would not be best suited for calls. This isn't an issue for me as I don't call a ton throughout the day. The audio quality is really similar to Jabras and perfect for casual listeners when used with a larger earbud tip. I thought this would be a bad compromise and hurt my ears for better sound quality but haven't had any comfort issues. These are the lightest while being the most secure headphones I've had. Definitely the best Bluetooth headphones I've bought yet and I have only had them a day. I have a Galaxy Note 9 so the app for these is a must.

author: Stavros
title: Great Buds! Dont hesitate to buy em!
content:
After leaving the iPhone fan group and switching to a new Samsung S10+, I was initially very skeptical as to the quality of these buds.

I should have never been worried! These are amazing! The case which holds the buds is very sleek and allows for wired or wireless charging. In addition, the buds have great battery life and the case provides even more juice on the go. What I truly like about these more than the typical apple airpods and other style buds is that they fit into your ear very nicely and they have an app that allows you to customize your sound settings for the type of music you normally listen to. They also have an ambient sound feature that allows you to hear people talking to you etc while you have them in your ears. It's a great feature!

If you're on the fence about getting these I would say just get them! They are worth the price and they definitely have comparable sound to Beats!

author: Eric Sebastian Rodriguez
title: Day 10: Amazing sound quality, Sleek, and Fun features
content:
Update 5/16/2019, Day 10: the headphones are working seamlessly now. I believe it was due to a few software updates for the driver's. I'm not sure but they work great now. I'm glad I did rush to return them. I have using them and sound quality is great.

Update 5/8/2019, Day 2: I did some trouble shooting. Reset my Earbuds and reinstalled app. I found if you continuously tap on the Device Name, which you will find if you click on About Earbuds in the Wearables app, you can test the headphones to see if they are functioning properly. I placed the headphones on my phone and started test. Test came out as Passing on all data. Now when you place the Earbuds in your ear it will state that the Proximity L and Proximity R FAIL which happens only when they are in your ear and means you need to take them off to get an accurate test. So far so good. Will possibly give 5 stars and may not return after all. Glad I tried trouble shooting.

Day 1: Just received the Galaxy Buds today. I love Samsung products. Usually very trusting of them. Sadly I got a defective pair. Very disappointing. The left earbud makes no indication of being placed in ear. I believe it's a sensor defect. The right earbud does make a sound when placed in ear. The app also shows me that ambient sound is not possible since both are not in my ear when they definitely are. I looked at both to make sure examine differences and their seems to be no visual differences. Looks like the sensor is defective one the left ear for my pair. Hopefully can receive a different pair that's not totally defective.

author: Ice Cold Pepsi
title: Issues after unboxing
content: When I spend over 100 dollars on a pair of headphones, I expect them to work properly, right out of the box.  First my left earbud was dead, now my right earbud can't deliver any audio out of its speaker.  I'm currently running my left earbud's battery into the ground with the intention to re-pair (lol) both earbuds at the same time.  I'm hoping this works and I don't have to drop another 100+ on the Jabra 65t.  This is unacceptable.

author: Kindle Customer
title: A steal at a third the price!
content:
The connection is finicky. For no apparent reason it will cut out randomly until docked in its case. Just now one of the buds began emitting a high pitched tone until docked for a minute... it seems to be degrading.

On top of that, the package I was sent was NOT as advertized. They sent me the case, buds, and a charger in a plastic bag. No differently-sized rubber bits (though Amazon sent me some for free since Samsung refused) and no manual. Plus the bag had a sticker claiming the device was new but it was a little dirty so I doubt that. I paid an extra like $40 for new not refurbished, so, I recommend not doing the same. They'll send you a refurbished device anyway.

As earbuds they're great. Occasionally redocking them is annoying but all bluetooth earbuds need to be recharged every several hours anyway so they work out to not be especially bad. But the false advertizing, hassle to get the correct pieces, degrading reliability, and high cost together have me giving this 2 stars. There are other brands so go for them instead. I regret buying these.

author: Ms.Tina
title: Best Earbuds Ever!
content: Ok so I was a little nervous purchasing these because the GearX was a huge disappointment but Samsung really fixed things with these. They come with 3 different size tips and I went up one size just to make sure they were totally snug and cancelled out noise. I travel frequently so these are perfect on planes especially. I am impressed with the battery life and unlike the previous version I can charge these and wear one then whenever it dies the other one is still fully charged and the case still will completely recharge the other one....The battery doesnt drain when not in use and that's a huge factor for me. Great price, well worth it. The only con I have that I wish the sound could go up a little louder and also would be perfect if you could adjust the sound on the actually bud....You can only adjust sound on your device its linked to. But other than that I love them!

author: Anthony Kongvongsai
title: Perfect Wireless Earbuds... for MY needs
content:
After a 4 month journey of trying to find the perfect wireless earbuds, I'm pleased to say the Galaxy Buds are perfect for my day to day needs.

Pros
 - very discreet earbuds. I like how they don't stick out of your ears like the Air Pods for example.

- If you have a Samsung phone, there is an App where you can adjust the sound profile. Though I personally didn't hear a huge difference, you can also adjust the ambient noise where it allows you to hear the environment around you. This was a huge plus for me, and it works very well.

- the travel case is small, and discreet as well. Doesn't leave a big buldge in your pocket or anything. I never found myself running out of battery on my earbuds on any day. I can wear my earbuds up to 3 hours at a time at %30-50 volume.

- sound quality is above average. at this price point, I didn't have Godly like expectations where I would be getting Sennheiser True Wireless like sound stage. Those earbuds cost more than double, so let's be realistic here people.

-you CAN wear one earbud at a time if you would like, regardless if it's the left or right earbud. Doesn't matter. I didn't realize how much this mattered to me until I used it for a longer period of time. In comparison, the Jabra Elite can only wear one earbud if it's the RIGHT earbud. The left cannot play music alone. That was a huge deal breaker for me, as for you.. you can decide if that matters. When you take out the earbud when wearing both, music does not pause on the other one you're wearing it and vice versa. When you're just wearing one earbud and decide to put in the second one, music continues playing and it's a smooth transition.

- can be charged wirelessly, on a s10/s10+. I didn't use this feature much, but it's cool knowing they it's there. It charges much slower on your phone vs a direct wired connection

Cons:

- this is not a deal breaker for me, but it may be for you. It's not water resistant. I think it can only take an x amount of sweat, but you don't wanna get these drenched in water. These are not advertised as workout headphones so I'm personally completely fine with it. I have a separate earbuds for that scenario.

-though the case is small, everytime I dropped it my earbuds always fly out of the case. I wish it didn't open that easily with drops. So don't drop your earbuds in the case

- to my surprise, I haven't used it much for phone calls. But from what I heard from other YouTube reviewers, they say call quality is terrible in noisy environments. Callers have a hard time hearing you, so try to be in a quiet environment if possible.

- the earbuds have gestures to pause/skip tracks, answer and ignore calls. I used mine primarily for music. one thing I noticed, which might POSSIBLY be a user error on my end.. but every now and then the Buds don't register my touches. Example. When I double tap to skip track, sometimes it registers only 1 tap and the song pauses. Minor annoyance, but something to be aware of. I think you have to hit the earbuds perfectly rather than just the edge of your finger. another thing I noticed is if you're listening to music and you skip a few tracks on your music Playlist, each time you hit double tap I feel like the earbuds are getting pushed deeper and deeper into my ear canal, and it's discomforting. I wish in the future maybe they do a swipe feature as a gesture to skip and go back to a track rather than the double/triple tap.

author: Andy
title: Absolutely LOVE These
content: These earbuds are AMAZING. I absolutely love them. They sound amazing for both music and voice. They work well for phone calls, music, videos, podcasts, etc. They literally work perfectly for everything. They will connect to ANY bluetooth device. I frequently switch these from my phone to my laptop and it couldn't work better. However, if you're just using them with one device, they automatically connect when you open the case. It's amazing. They sound good, they're easy to use, and they come with different size pieces to hold them in your ears comfortably. Works good for the gym, as well, because they sit snug in your ears without the need for the wrap around the outside of your ears that some earbuds have. 5 stars, highly recommend!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Totally worth it for a great price
content:
So far I absolutely love these earbuds. They fit well and sound perfect to my simple ears. Ambient sound is a great addition, but you have to turn it on every time. The touch controls are going to take some getting used to, but they're not better or worse than any other set up. Also love that you can just use one without the other without any finagling. They look discreet in your ear and the case is small enough to fit in my pocket along with everything else.

Edit: if you're earbuds don't seem very loud switch the long press to volume and turn the volume up there, then control it with your phone. I found my volume wasn't synced and turning it up on the headphones separately made them much louder.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Underwhelming, unacceptable given the price point
content:
I know $120 is pretty cheap given the general price points of true wireless earbuds st the moment, but given the brand and the official reviews, I expected better. This is from someone who has an iPhone, so maybe the app makes all the difference, in which case, Samsung is missing out on a huge chunk of their potential market by not having an iOS app.

First of all — the earbuds are heavy. This is going to happen, since unlike wired earbuds, they have to have the battery, etc. I was able to mostly forget about them, but after a while my ears began to ache. They provide you with alternative fins and buds, and I swapped through all of them trying to find a comfortable fit. I thought I had, and went to compare to my current (5€) earbuds — nope. The difference is stark and uncomfortable.

The sounds were flat at best, muffled at worst. I played around with the Spotify EQ for over two hours trying to get something that resembled reasonable sound. This is apparently where the app shines through, well. I’m not an audiophile by any means. I listen to music/podcasts 9 hours of my day, however, and this just doesn’t cut it. I

If these were 50$ buds, I’d give 4 stars. At more than double that, this doesn’t cut it. I’m bummed, as I hate AirPods and was hoping to find an Alternative.

author: Michael R
title: They were choppy at first
content: I'm not sure what to make of this I got them, used them they were laggy and choppy. First thing I did was charge them to full and still.... laggy and choppy. I thought maybe they were just crap product, but after like 3 - 4 hours of use they just synced up or something? I'm not sure but it has worked perfectly post 4 hour mark.

author: JimD
title: Cuts out constantly with Samsung Galaxy S7
content: The mic quality is VERY poor...unusable .  The buds continually cut out unless I hold the phone within 12"..  It could be that the older Bluetooth version of the phone is not distance-compatible with the newer version of Bluetooth.  I cannot get ANY cordless earbuds to work with the Samsung S7, with the exception of an older version which the buds are wire connected to each other.

author: Brian C
title: Worth the prize!
content: I love these! Battery lasts me longer than expected, loving the touch feature and how I can have one on while one charges or I need one ear open. If you think they sound very low just go to touch pad, and edit settings to increase the volume on them separately from your device! Thought they were broken but it was jut volume settings! Love them and can't get enough of them. Not a single complaint or issue either! I've had them for 2 weeks now and still can't get enough of them! Recommended!!!

author: Brad Beatty
title: Fabulous!
content:
These things are superb. They sound nice, and they are simply fun to have.
- Very secure in your ear - they do not fall out.  Ever.  They are also very comfortable, even to sleep in.
- Super easy to pair Bluetooth.  Seamless.
- Each earbud is independent - you can use either L or R by themselves if you wish, and you can switch on-the-go.  No hassle.
- No stupid LEDs blinking all over the place
- Very pleasant audio cues - no talking like other annoying earbuds I own
- Neat features, like they automatically pause when you take them out of your ear.  Just tap to re-start.
- After two months of heavy use, I have never had a battery use all of its charge during use.
- The charging case is nice and simple.

author: Michael R
title: Worst earbuds I have ever owned!
content: Sometimes the sound isn't very loud sometimes it fine. Biggest complaint is if you are in a loud room you cannot hear the person you are talking too and they cannot hear you. 1st. pair died within two weeks the second pair just after the Amazon return window. Luckily I purchased the extended warranty for them. Save yourself the hassle, go check out the new Jabra elite, because I think that will be my next purchase!

author: Polysics
title: New daily carry headphones
content:
I use these every. single. day.

They are just fantastic. They replaced my Jabra Elite 65t's for a handful of reasons I will explain below.

1. They are smaller and lighter: Maaaaan they are so much smaller and lighter. The Jabra's are like little onion bulbs in my ear. Now don't get me wrong, the Jabra's fit my ears wonderfully, they get great points for ergonomics, but the Jabra's are just too heavy, and they are on the large side. They don't fit small persons ears (i've tested it on friends and family with small ears and they are a no.) These Galaxy Buds on the other hand, are suuuper lightweight, and their "pyramid" shape is very ergonomic to the ear (at least mine, YMMV as always!) The other thing about the Jabra's are that one earbud is sliiiiightly heavier than the other, and man oh man, I could feel it all the time. It always felt like the heavier earbud was pulling on itself. The Galaxy Buds do not suffer from that issue, as they both are feather light and comfy AF.

2. Independent usage and control versatility: The earbuds controls are on both sides, and you can use EITHER earbud by itself. This is such a damn problem with 99% of earbuds out there. Other than some obscure Chinese OEM that may have that feature (which are mostly garbage), the only mainstream brand earbuds that share this same feature are the Apple Airpods. Being able to use either earbud by itself is super important to me. Be it walking around and being aware of my surroundings, or having one in while working. There are many situations where I use just one bud, and having the option of either side is wonderful. The added thing that many don't think of is that if you are going to be listening for a particularly long time (say to an audiobook/podcast all day long) then you can get continuous usage until you use up all the juice in the charging case. If you have one in and it gets low, just swap it out and let the dead one charge. You can't do that with all the earbuds that have a "master/slave" configuration where one bud is dependent on the other bud. Having the same controls on both sides (minus the tap-hold if you choose to use it for volume) is equally important in that regard, so you don't have to pull out your phone or use a smartwatch to do functions like pause and next and previous. ALL TRUE WIRELESS EARBUDS SHOULD BE ABLE TO FUNCTION INDEPENDENTLY.

3. Modern charging standards: USB C and Qi charging. Enough said. Everything is going C or Qi, so thank you Samsung for making it modern. The less cables I have to carry and/or buy, the better. Micro USB was a standard, but it's time has passed, and it needs to die gracefully. Don't even get me started on that one company's proprietary cables that they force down peoples throats and wallets...

4. Svelte charging case, "pocket-ergonomic": the only other earbuds worth a piss on the market that have a svelte and small charging case are (of course) the Apple AIrPods. They are still the king on the pocket-able size and shape of their product. Samsung is damn close though with the Galaxy Buds. They are very svelte, and their feeling in the pocket is just as good (as in, you hardly notice they are there) as the AirPods. Yes, some other earbud cases are "squatter" and some are "skinnier" but the other's don't get the shape right, so they always end up feeling like a fat stone in your pocket. The Galaxy Buds case melts into your leg and you don't even notice it's there (unless maybe your partial to skinny jeans. My experience is with standard jeans and slacks)

All in all, these hit all the sweet spots for price, style (no more toothbrushes thanks,) function, ergonomics, sound quality (better than AirPods, about on par with Jabra's. Don't expect B&O sound quality) and features. I don't think there is a better set of true wireless earbuds under $200. And to be honest, the concessions that some of the over $200 ones make you suffer is a dealbreaker.

If you want great wireless buds, these are the ones.

author: Deborah J. Lambert
title: Defective Bluetooth
content: I knew 10 minutes into my first use of this product that I was going to return these earbuds. The sound in the left earbud dropped out intermittently. I wore my phone on my left arm in an armband and the connection was still terrible.  I found that if I looked to the right with my head level while walking, they worked great, but the moment you moved your head back to straight ahead or down and the music dropped out. For $127, I would have expected a much better product from Samsung.

author: Omar Alkhadra
title: Day 1: so far so good, impressed. Day 30: ?
content:
Will do an update on day 30 and whether ive decided that i want to keep them or not.

Day 1 of using these wireless buds.
These are my first pair of truly wireless headphones. $130 is not little for me so I have watched every video review and read every article out there.  I was very skeptical because of the bad microphone reviews everybody gave it, as my MAIN USE for it is phone calls. Did multiple calls through out the day with no problems with sound or the other party not hearing me. Have had some issues with connecting them to my laptop and the left earbud stopped working for a while, but i think that was related to the case running out of battery cuz i connected and started using them right out the box didnt plug them in at all. There was weird static in the buds while connected to the laptop, none of that while connected to the phone tho. So that might be from my laptop idk. Again ive had these for only one day so far.
Initial impression is so far so good. Very impressive noise cancellation and GOOD sound quality. Very light in the ear, can wear them for extended amount of time with no fatigue. Glad they had replacement "wings" as what comes on by default didnt sit good with my ear so those come handy. Case is very small and easy to carry around. Stay posted for update in a month.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Horrible for making phone calls
content: I bought mine when they first came out. Returned then about 30 days later. On my second pair and am ready to return them after only a week. Initial impression was they are awesome, music sound quality was great. Good for in my ear, used them all the time, in my yard while gardening. As earbuds and blue tooth device for work while traveling. The issue is when using them as a Bluetooth device for phone calls people in the other end hear a loud metallic clacking noise and can barely hear me. With out the ability to use them for phone calls these amount to a $130 paper weight, absolutely useless. Very disappointed. Not to mention the hoops I had to jump through with Samsung for the return.

author: Randall
title: Extremely Dissatisfied
content: I have had these for 3 days now and already I'm experiencing major issues. First, the ambient noise on the left earpiece wasn't working. Then the left earpiece started cutting out audio constantly. Afterwards, after about 20 minutes, the video and audio become out of sync and audio is lagging behind the video slightly. NOW ON THE THIRD DAY the audio of both earbuds are out of sync with each other and the left piece is lagging behind the right making an annoying echo effect. I'm so frustrated, I was so excited to finally get these, but now I'm extremely disappointed and am about to return them. All the reviews I read and watched spoke highly of these, but alas, I was let down.

author: elvira buenavrnte
title: could be better.
content:
Really disappointed with these wireless earbuds. As a galaxy s10e user I have no choice this is the Best option but at a cost. Battery life is meh gets you through the day, sound quality is flat and bass is poor. The tap features are a hit or miss mostly with the triple tap to go back to the previous track, if you press it to fast it will skip or pause, if you tap to slow it will skip or pause you would have to be a human metronome to get it right. The biggest disappointment is the microphone. ABSOLUTE TRASH!! your voice is inaudible over the phone and if you want hear your surroundings just take the earbuds off, you wont regret going the extra step that you didn't have to do if it was better. I also have the airpods 2 and I have done the comparison, sound quality the airpods win with a good balance of highs, mids and and acceptable standard of bass but just with ambient sound permanently on because of its design. The case has wireless charging and the pill design makes it compact and clean, opening the case requires 2 hands, not a joke. When closing it feels like a rusted door you have to apply some pressure and it makes a satisfying click imitating the airpods that do this with ease.

Overall just get these for convenience of wireless earbuds. Sound is ok so sure why not.

author: All Might
title: True wireless headphones with amazing quality. Say goodbye to the wire-tangled life.
content:
First and foremost, I'm a dedicated runner, getting in between 8-10 miles each day, 5 days  a week, at 9 mph constantly- not including the distances traveled while walking at work or running errands. The remaining 2 days are for limited hit-cardio, but even then, I'll squeeze 3 miles at an uncomfortable pace of 10.5 for that burn. These buds STAY INSIDE YOUR EARS no matter how much you move around. That doesn't mean go crazy and start headbanging, but their very resistant to high intensity workouts. Just be conscious of them. Both are incredibly light and there are different ear tips for the buds should they not fit well. Different topic- but ..sometimes your phone/smartwatch, will register the run, other times it'll register it as just walking...either which way you're still getting a wire-free experience.

Ambient sound can be a tad irritating, and the touch controls MIGHT not respond accurately, but this is purely situational.
Their comfortable, fit securely, and are easy to use. controlling them through the Samsung gear app is also convenient.
It allows you to check the charge level of each ear bud, the connectivity status, control the notifications preference for what apps can be controlled via touch on the buds, touch-pad preference, etc.
So overall usage is wonderful, UX from feedback was definitely taken into account, and the UI with simple to remember taps to skip a song, a few songs, a whole track, answer and decline calls based on what bud is tapped, and more is incorporated into these.

author: Blev
title: From 5 stars to 2 stars.  Horrible for making calls
content:
I hate to see earbuds compared to airpods as airpods look very unigue and don't even use Bluetooth. That said, there are better then average sounding true wireless bud.  They have are highly comfortable if you get the fin, tip setting perfect. Battery life is amazing for the size.  I purchased blacks ones on Amazon and lost the charging case so elsewhere I purchased the Yellow.  As you can see I blended the colors of each but which will help me not lose the black ones.  I am overall very happy and find myself reaching for these and SoundPeats almost exclusively despite the fact that I own about 10 pairs of true wireless. Samsung goes as far as saying they are great for calls!; Though I don't use my airpods and dispute the fact they they are still me go to buds, they are NOT better then airpods because with airpods people don't even know you are using them on a call?
I am officially losing faith in the marketing claims made by the big brands as the no name Chinese inports own this market now

author: Amazon Kunde
title: Great for non-audiophiles
content: I got these a while ago, and had issues with them at first. The Bluetooth connection was spotty and would cut out if I bent over, it was bad. HOWEVER, it turns out that it was just my set. I called Samsung, since they were still under warranty, and they sent me a new pair, perfectly functioning. They have, in my opinion, amazing battery life. I have only ever ran them all the way down once, and they last a day, guarantee for me.  That 6 hour battery life is legit. The call quality is pretty good. I've never had someone not understand me while using them for calls, and I have used them both inside and outside. As for fit, they do take a little getting used to. But if you do manage to find the right combo of wings and tips, then they seal your ear fairly well. I usually can't understand people talking to me if music is playing, and it is definitely muffle when there isn't music playing. The environmental awareness feature is ok, it really does just make stuff sound tinny, but for what it is intended for, it works. The touch controls are decent; sometimes if I don't tap enough towards the center of the touch pad, it won't read, but it is responsive once you get the hang of it. The wireless charging is absolutely ingenious. I have an ikea desk lamp with a wireless charger, and I just throw them on overnight, and that's that. There is a USB-C if that suits your fancy too. Finally, the sound quality. I think they are pretty good. I am no audiophile, so as long as you aren't OBSESSED with the sound quality, they will do just fine. They do have bass, contrary to popular belief, though it will not be bass you FEEL. What I mean is, you won't feel the bass as well as hear it, like with a sub-woofer or something. The "equalizer" in the wearable app does have a "dynamic" setting that provides the best balance in my opinion; the "bass boost" just lowers mids and trebles, so it isn't really great. Overall, they are an excellent set of headphones that I take literally anywhere, especially since they are so dang compact.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Overly fancy

author: matt white
title: Great Sound. Cool Concept
content: The Samsung Galaxy Buds are a great set of ear buds. They offer solid sound while keeping them small and compact. They charge in a wonderful little black case. The case also charges wireless which works great with the Samsung wireless charger I use on my desk already. You can use one at a time or both. So far I've tried them listening to music and placing some phone calls, both sound great and clear. I tried the music and the calls using one ear bud and both. The ear buds over all are pretty comfortable in the ear and aren't terribly noticeable. The first time i used them i thought the volume was very quite, even with my phone volume completely turned up. I found these have an internal volume and just needed to be turned up. There is a nice app you can use to configure the buds to how you want them. I configured the touch button on the ear bud to adjust volume and simply just turned it up. The touch button can be used to play/pause music, answer/hang up phone calls, and skip and go back on music tracks, all in addition to the volume control i mentioned above. The pair with the phone was very simply. All i did was open up the app and tell it I had some ear buds. I can't wait to try these at different opportunities coming up this summer. So far i give the product a 5 star review as i haven't found anything negative about them.

author: JimmyD
title: Great buds for music, but poor call quality
content:
- Excellent ear buds if I don't have to make any calls. As with many other users on Samsung forum, sound quality is good locally, but the other person on a call hears pops/static/garbage. (Users report this problem remains even after reset & exchange for new pair!)

As a user of AirPods, Nuheara IQBuds, and Sony WH-1000XM3s, I am now using these as my daily drivers with good sound on “Dynamic” mode in the Equalizer within the Galaxy Wearable app. Sound quality isn't as good as my WH-1000XM3s, but these are certainly more discreet and appropriate for one-bud driving and work.

- Initially upon pairing with my Note 9 and testing with my favorite testing song (you have one, right?) the volume was simply too low. I tried everything but couldn't get it to go to more than maybe 50% volume even though the system said they were maxed.
LOW VOLUME FIX: Had to go into Android “developer settings,” check “Disable Absolute Volume” and reboot… only then was the volume fixed. Pairing with iPad Pro 11 and iPhone X had no volume issues and good sound.

- Good overall balance between price and quality.  On the Dynamic setting, sound is similar to Apple airPods.  AirPods can sound artificially “processed,” which is not the case in the Galaxy Buds.

- Although these aren't actively noise blocking, the design blocks enough that people will have to shout for you to hear them.  For the sound blocking to be effective (and to have good bass) you must rotate the buds after you place the tip in your ear to put them in the correct position in the ear canal.  Rotate counter-clockwise for the optimal fit.

- We tested call quality and microphone quality by calling my teenage daughter's phone. She said my airPods sounded like I was talking through a bag, and Galaxy Buds sounded clear. Good enough!!

- We expected ambient sound control similar to Sony WH-1000 series or Nuheara IQBuds, but Galaxy Buds controls were primitive and less effective by comparison.  Ambient sounds coming in are mixed in but sound tinny… not a big issue for me, but the Sony WH-1000Mx3 win the prize here with ambient sounds mixed in that sound natural with “focus on voice” settings that actually work, unlike the same setting for these Galaxy Buds, which seemed to have very little effect.

- Ambient sound is only needed when both earbuds are in, so the option is greyed out if only one is in.  [NOW FIXED: There's a software issue with ambient sound where if you only use one bud after having both in, ambient sound controls cannot be turned back on even if you then place both in your ears.]

- Volume control can be configured with long-press on the left (volume down) and long-press on the right (volume up).  If you only use one bud at a time, this doesn’t work of course. Interestingly, volume appears to be independent of the Android's media volume setting (i.e., you could max media volume on your phone and then turn it up even louder with the earbuds)

- Battery life is good… can easily get full day alternating left/right, and battery percentage shown in Galaxy Wearable app is often visible.  You cannot see the case’s charge except in 1/3 increments.  When the case is unplugged, open the case and then close it again.  The front LED will show green, yellow, and red for rough charge left in the case.  Using both earbuds all day should theoretically be possible since there should be 2+ charges in the case, providing 18 hours of play (17 hours in my tests) before everything dies. Like the Nuheara IQBuds, you can't turn things “off” when charging in the case, so eventually things will likely run out even if you're not using them.  Definitely use a higher amp base charger to charge the case quickly.

- Size is easily as good as airPods for the case slipping into a pants pocket. However, the slick non-textured case surface means it could slip out of my pocket while seated or lying down.

- Can locate a lost bud though Galaxy Wearable app, but just as with iOS and airPods, you cannot locate the base (which you'll recall likes to fall out of pocket due to its slippery surface)

- The Galaxy Buds reads notifications?  Yay! Right? We expected functionality similar to free Android app “Out Loud” by hillman apps, which can read your text messages or Facebook messages or other notifications out loud. Sadly, the Galaxy Wearable provided only very basic functionality, only reading app name and no details.  (So instead of reading the full text message, it says only “Messenger.”) Not very useful.

- Overall… I've been waiting for someone to come along with something better than the Apple airPods, and I've always been disappointed that no one could beat the airPods -- until now. I'm now using these every day. Many of the issues above can be resolved with firmware/software updates, so I'm more than pleased with the capabilities and quality in this (early but related to consumer) state.

author: Areyouin44
title: Pros outweigh cons, best with Samsung phones
content:
Great headphones, work extremely well with Samsung phones. They block noise very well which is a pro for workouts and noisy offices but a con for situational awareness. Battery life is amazing.

The case is super slick, like fall out of your pocket slick.

Sound quality is.... Interesting.... If you jam the things in your ears, like uncomfortably so, then they sound good. If you try to let them hang out a bit so they are more comfortable and you can hear around you better, then the sound quality drops significantly. Bass is the most affected, but honestly the pros far outweigh the cons.

I have a lot of bluetooth headsets and these are the best on balance. However I'd like to stress that if you are going to wear them long term, like all day at work, then airpods are much better. After a few hours with these in they start to really hurt my ears.

I wish they'd have a smaller eartip than what's included like the old Moto Hint from back in the day.

author: Josh
title: Major connection issues
content: The sound is decent if they stay connected. There is an echo that happens as well normally when using them when talking on the phone. Paired with a Galaxy S10+. I was willing to overlook the disconnecting. Even the echo as it normally stops after 15 to 30 seconds. But losing sound in one side is just bad. I could still hear the chime if I pushed the touchpad and the earbud was connected as it could still control the music. It would just stop playing the music out of one earbud. I would not reccomend unless you plan on using one earbud at a time. Then it might be ok although you will lose the ambient sound feature.

author: JustNick
title: Never liked airbud till these came along.
content:
Man oh man, did these take me by surprise, let me say straight up they Actually sound very Good, i'd rate the sound response and quality as follows:
Treble- 10
Bass - 7.8 [not surprised but they are good thou, not perfect but they are buds so maybe it's perfect based on price and technological limitations]
Mids/Vocals - 9 [damn right]

So here's some quick pros n cons while i'm here;

Pros:
- easy to pair and the App is very intuitive
- the carrying case is perfectly sized and if you been reading online or watching videos you know the S10 line can charge it via the case wirelessly and it uses USB C!!! lol so nice
- Like i mentioned before the sound is pretty good, i paid 120bucks and i'm not mad, i spent way more for less quality in the past.

Cons - sound quality for all i know could be better, i just based it as good in comparison to all the other non popular buds out there.
- it works seamlessly with Samsung devices but not with apple, little glitches here and there but nothing major. just shows either apple don't like buds or samsung purposely made them to glitch with apple.... both parties suck IMO....

that's all for now [05/24/2019] i'll update if something happens or i discover something. as for now, they get my vote of approval [for droid users anyways] apple users stick to your Airpods, why even try it when it will glitch from time to time more often than not?

~Peace~

author: Dimitri C. Karbo
title: Good value for money!
content: I was reading all these o star reviews and honestly I cannot understand tham.  Truth is sound quality is not the best as they do lack good deep bass but the sound overall is good! Noise cancelation is good if you fit them properly in your ear. For those complaining about the low volume it can be configured via the application. Pairing and configuration was relatively straight forward. The touch buttons will take a while to get used to them. The lack of actual buttons if a drawback. Phone calls are loud and clear on both sides of the line.  And I get no interruptions even walking far from my phone. The design is a plus and during workout they stay in place with no issues.

author: Monica M.
title: Enjoy a snug fit and lasting battery life!
content: Wow! I am so surprised with these headphones. I mainly bought these to do yard work and was unsure if they would stay in my ears. I was so surprised when i could do literally anything with these in my ears and they wouldn't fall out. Downside, they can been a little uncomfortable after a while but I also haven't tried to use any of the different ear pieces that came in the box. The sound quality is pretty good, if you are looking for a headphone with a lot of low end bass, these are not your headphones. They have a nice dynamic sound but I wish they had a little more bass to them. I also don't understand or used the ambient sound feature it made everything just sound like static. I really hope Samsung starts including them in the box of their latest phones and dare I say get rid of the headphone jack.

author: Malik Harris
title: Disappointing on non-Samsung Devices
content: I really wanted to like these headphones. Paired with my Galaxy S10, they sounded good (though not Bose quality, which I'm a bit biased towards anyway), they connected easily, and felt comfortable. It was great having no wires to worry about at all. However, this whole experience is CRIPPLED by the fact that these buds suck on any other device that's not made by Samsung. I often use my home computer and work computer to listen to music, videos, etc. And these headphones sound TERRIBLE on those devices, both Windows computers. Sure, I can download an equalizer to improve this, but I shouldn't have to. And there's no official Samsung Windows app either, so I can't adjust anything that I would be able to adjust on my phone. They could at least make it so that the headphones remember the settings from your phone. My previous Bose Soundsport Wireless sounded the same on every device, no downloading or adjusting the equalizer or anything. Now, if you just use these with your Galaxy and no other device, they're fine. But this limited functionality is just lame, and it's a shame that Airpods work and sound better on other devices compared to these, right out of the box. Really disappointed.

author: Melvyn Owens
title: Not bad!
content: Ok so I have a little experience with earbuds now, and here's the deal. I owned a pair of Jabra elite 65t's and so I'm kinda compairing. Samsung's sound is pretty good, I been listening for the last 5 hours at a somewhat elevated volume. The left one lasted longer at 25% right one 15%. The signal kinda got fuzzy once or twice but quickly corrected itself. I had to change the eartip and piece that fits into my ear to the larger one that made the sound much better. I don't like the touch pad on the earbuds as it makes it too easy to pause the music accidentally. Downloaded the app for earbuds from Google play that helps. Oh, and when you turn it up loud the treble seems just a bit too high the music is not even. It has good bass to me. But honestly Jabra elite are awesome the only issue was they just slightly too big for my ear and after awhile uncomfortable but the sound is amazing even without the eq. But still I feel like I'm settling with the galaxies. It's like driving a Camry after driving a Lexus ehh! It'll do.

author: B. Fowler
title: Horrible Bluetooth
content: I got these this morning, charged the  up, connected to my phone and download the software update. Then I disconnected from my phone and paired with my Galaxy Watch 46mm LTE and set out for a walk. The moment I went outside, the audio started cutting in and out. The only way the audio stays clear is if I hold the watch under my chin. (This does not happen with the same watch and my older pair of airpods) The moment I drop my hand, it's like someone is trying to communicate to me frantically in muted Morse Code. Buyers remorse like a mf at the moment. I called Samsung for help and they told me to try and clean them. They are hours old. Then I was referred back to Amazon. I've looked everywhere online, and this seems to be a big problem with no fix.

author: Saiks
title: Very Comfy Earbud
content: This is hands down the most comfortable Earbuds I have ever owned. No ear fatigue what so ever and comes with 3 sets of tips for the best possible fit. For something this small, I didn't expect the sound quality to be that great, however its the opposite. Audio quality is one of the best in its category and features a built in equalizer to customization. I can hear the highs and lows very well even when on a call in a noisy environment. Wireless charging case is a great added feature even a quick 10 mins of charging gives me about 40 mins of musics. If you have a Samsung Galaxy S10 variants, you can use the PowerShare feature to charge the case. Love the Find My Earbuds feature which send out an audible sound to direct you to it location(they do want you to find them). Ambient sound to hear your surrounding. Hear your Notifications and customizable touchpad. Samsung has done a great job with these Earbuds and is definitely a must buy if your are in the market for one as they work with Android, iOS and other bluetooth devices.

author: LB7
title: Spend a little more. These are worth it
content:
Case battery seems weak compared to the buds. If you own a galaxy phone and make calls as well as use headphones for productivity, you need these.
Very pocket-able, last all day, great sound for their size and weight, touch controls, pass trhu mode (although imperfect) all work excellent. I waited way too long to get these. If you are getting a new phone, do not buy! I heard a lot of carriers give these out with a galaxy phone purchase.
I use these for just about everything, and the anti lag integration on galaxy phones makes videos enjoyable (did not work on my 2017 MBP)
I came from bose earbuds and quiet comforts, and these bridged the gap to the sealed-in-ear style. Nothing else i tried stayed in, and i generally hate the standard sealed in ear style because it slowly works its way out.  Even tried a china knockoff for like 60, not worth it. Returned.

author: Marco J. DeConno
title: Had to return them
content:
Had to return them.
First, I had to go online for setup instructions as the documentation was all in another language (I'm assuming Uruguay as that is what the outside packaging reflects - even though U.S. is advertised here on Amazon).
After charging the Buds completely and ensuring all updates have been installed,  no one could hear me if there was the slightest outside noise (a oscillating room fan, on low setting 10 feet away, prevented people from hearing me) and if I was in a completely silent room,  I sounded muffled to everyone.
The Buds, however, felt good in the ear and were fairly loud but had zero bass even though the settings were all correct.

author: JB
title: Sounds great but connection cut out
content: I really enjoyed the galaxy buds when I first got them but after a day of using them it sounded like they were cutting out. Both buds would randomly cut out in the middle of a song and would continue for about 2 minutes until I turned off the buds and reconnected them. I also have a galaxy watch, so I wonder if the simultaneous connection of my phone to my buds and watch may have caused the bad connection. The buds themselves also could've been faulty. Either way I just returned them because it was too big of a problem too soon after I bought them. Otherwise comfort and sound were great. Really disappointed I couldn't keep them.

author: Alex Fleming
title: Top tier Wireless Earbuds
content: I bought a few different wireless earbuds, hoping to get good audio quality out of some cheapos to replace my current pair. Unfortunately, they were all awful in various ways: too quiet, didn't fit ear, dig to deep into ear canal, uncomfortable, and some other minor things. I forgot these existed, so when I was reminded I bought them immediately. Absolutely stand out quality, cool technology, fits my ear like a freaking glove when others didn't even come close. Amazing audio quality, great battery life (haven't tested/paid enough attention to the battery life), but they last me throughout a 9 hour work day with only being charged for maybe 20-30 minutes without a problem. I won't get into specs or what kind of cool technology is inside these, other reviews will handle that. I just wanted to express my love for these.

author: MDamion.Yahoo
title: Older devices and connecting to Linux Operating System wasn't suited out of the box.
content:
My first impression was the sound wasn't all that impressive as the reviewers lead me to believe; even on my old Memopad 7 (with the various settings tweaked out on the jetAudio Plus music app). Bass is definitely lacking, and the boost from the Galaxy Wearable app improved it ever so slightly. When paired to my Apple iPod 7th Gen, the volume levels are maxed out to a medium-low. And with the Galaxy Buds long tap right/left controls to raise/lower the volumes are all but non-functional. The problem also occurs when synced to my Ubuntu 18.04 Desktop OS. Installing the Galaxy Plugins didn't help either.
I'm almost positive that the Buds would have had excellent sound with the Nano and I would have decided to keep them for that reason alone. It's probably just a flick of a switch in the firmware to make it possible and keep more customers from returning their products. Hopefully, the firmware gods will hear my pleas.

author: douglas rodrigue
title: These earbuds are great for the price , no need to look further
content:
Just got my Galaxy Buds in after hearing weeks of the hype of how good these buds were ,finally after 1 week.  I opened the box and immediately it was synced.  That was the first amazing thing. Secondly was putting them on and the snug fit. Next I tried listening to a quality song on YouTube.  And I was blown away at the quality of the sound. It was amazing.  I could hear different debts of the instruments in the songs.  I had been trying to upgrade from wired earphones for awile but didn't want to waste money and time on the wrong upgrade.  Man, was this rewarding.  Now I have been telling my friends about this every since I have been having them.  They are definitely worth the money.  I'm very happy with these now. I don't see myself ordering more earbuds . These are a keeper. Sound is amazing.
Comfortable to wear.  Many things to discover. Another fine Samsung product.

author: Mariana
title: I love these!!
content: I love how they don't fall out of my ears. The little rubber support thing that looks like a shark fin kinda didn't go well with my ear anatomy lmao but these headphones come with extra ring things and one of the pairs doesn't have that fin thing that sticks out and it makes them so comfortable to wear. I like that I can really move around and they still stay put. Also, the sound quality is insane. The noise-canceling is out of this world, they literally block all the sound. I think there is an app you can connect these headphones into and control the amount of noise canceling if its too much for you but I'm not sure because I have an iPhone and the app is only for Samsungs but just the fact that there is an app that also works with these sounds awesome.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great wireless earbuds!
content:
These are very convenient and I like having a wireless pair. Easy to go running with and to sleep with. The sound quality isnt bad but it isnt anything special. Its like the akg ones in the Samsung s9+ package. They are a little bulky but you can still sleep comfortably with some maneuvering.

The case is very nice and it charges them wirelessly. All you have to do is charge them inside the case once in a while. The battery life is pretty good, I use them pretty much everyday for exercising and before sleeping.

They are small and easy to fit in your pocket. Happy to not have to deal with tangled wires anymore in my pocket which makes it worth it. Also I don't have to deal with wires when I'm exercising.

They connect to your Samsung s9 almost instantly when you take them out of the case and put them in your ears. The single tap and double tap feature is very useful too. The noise cancellation is something I dont really need or use often. I like loud music when I'm exercising and I put the volume up to 80% of the max volume and that cancels my loud footsteps and breathing. I dont think I have noise cancellation on. The Samsung wearable Pp is pretty helpful too and I use it for the bass boost eq sometimes.

Overall I give it a 4.1 out of 5.

author: Amazon Customer
title: So secure!
content: I love these. I have tried with all of my being to get them to fall out and I can't. They are incredibly secure in my ears. Some have said that they don't have good quality sound, but I think they sound very good. I'm no audiophile though. I just think if you're looking for a good quality set of wireless buds, these can't be beat. I am able to do cross training as I normally would and never have to worry about having a bud come out, which can't be said for most wired buds I've owned.

author: MJM1972
title: Disappointing Call Quality
content:
Purchased these buds for use while I travel (70% of the time). I am very familiar with Samsung products, and was excited about these after reading the upgrades over previous versions.

Pros:
Compact, lightweight, very comfortable. I can wear them for hours without any discomfort. I even wear them while running and they do not move.
Sound quality is good. Noise canceling is decent considering that it is only passive. I spend a lot of time on planes and they work well I blocking background noises.

Cons:
Battery life and charging. Will only get about 3 hours of continuous use. A pain if you spend long periods of time on a plane. Also, charging is inconsistent across the buds. I have had the left bud not charge at all several times.

My biggest issue with these buds has been call quality. They are absolutely horrendous!  The microphone muffled your voice, all the while picking up every little sound around you. I have found improved performance indoors, but absolutely useless outdoors and in noisy environments like airports. Totally defeats the purpose of why I bough them for.

If you are looking for good buds for listening to your favorite tunes, then these are a good choice. If you’re like me and are also needing to use them for calls, I do not recommend them.

author: Jose Luis Balderas
title: Yup these earphones suck
content:
Where to begin. I recently bought these wireless earphones and kinda clueless why a lot of people give these earphones a good review. First and foremost the design is great. I love how they don't stick out like Q tips on your ears, and the charging design cool. Here's the bad part.

As I used them when walking to school or work during phone calls it tends to lose a lot of connectivity with both pods in my ear. It sounds like the ear phones are losing signal. Second, when using one pod. Prior who I am calling tell me that they can't hear me at all. Not sure why it keeps doing that. It's legit updated about three times since u got them but these earphones are bad quality. Being Samsung brand and akg I think I get better results buy another pair of airpods.

Lastly forgot to mention that the earphones case smell like burn plastic or of the box. Might be the issues.

author: Rob
title: they work for a month, don't trust warranty
content:
Wish i had just returned them to Amazon....

After a month the right earbud lost 80% volume. Look it up its an issue. I added the app, updated firmware, did everything on the forums and youtube to correct the right earbud. Let the wife have at it on her Iphone, my Pixel 3, everything thrown at them.

So instead of just returning them we went to Samsung, sent in for warranty instead of Amazon and now they have not sent any replacement for several weeks. I got one month of use. I sent them in to Samsung for warranty and now I guess i have to fight for the replacement set??? I have no earbuds working or not now.

 I would say its been a horrible experience with both the product and the manufacturer, don't buy Samsung Buds.

author: Cristian Cepeda
title: Very good headphones, not for everyone
content: I was really looking forward to these headphones when I purchased them, I really like what Samsung has done with these and Amazon offered the best shipping times on what seemed like was always selling out. They were extremely great, when they would fit in my ear. This is most likely a personal problem with my own ear other than anything else but they would not stay in my left ear no matter what wing tip or size I tried! I always had a problem with in ear buds but with this it was so much more apparent. I would definitely recommend to others but in the end I returned them due to this issue.

author: Sergio A Rodríguez Maurí
title: Very good sound
content: they are the best

author: Hector
title: Great, but blutooth issue
content: The baterry life, sound quality, and noise cancilation work great. The problem I've disscoved is with the blue tooth connection. When I walking with my phone in my pants pocket the sound cuts or skips at times. This occures too much in my opinion and can get easily annoying.

author: Kit K.
title: Small and easy to connect.
content:
